docs.title: Attestation Standard vs Reporting Standard
docs.text: Category Attestation Standard Reporting Standard Definition A framework that governs how a practitioner (e.g., auditor) performs an attestation engagement — where they evaluate and provide assurance on a subject matter based on someone else’s assertion. A framework that governs how the results of an engagement are communicated — including format, content, and required disclosures in the final report. Example SSAE 18 is an attestation standard used for SOC 1 & SOC 2 reports. The structure of a SOC 1 & SOC 2 report (sections like management assertion, system description, auditor’s opinion). Focus Methodology, independence, evidence gathering, and assurance level. Presentation, clarity, and completeness of the report. Used For SOC reports, financial forecasts, compliance reviews, etc. Audit reports, SOC reports, financial statements, etc.

docs.title: CIS’s - Critical Security Controls
docs.text: Developed by the Centre for Internet Security, the CIS Controls are a prioritized, prescriptive set of 18 safeguards that address the most common cyberthreats. Formerly known as SANS 20.

docs.title: Summary of the 18 controls
docs.text:
1. Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets: Managing all hardware devices connected to the infrastructure for monitoring and protection.

  2. Inventory and Control of Software Assets: Managing all software on the network, ensuring only authorized software is used.

  3. Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software: Maintaining secure settings for all assets and software.

  4. Account Management: Managing user account credentials and authorizations.

  5. Access Control Management: Managing access credentials and privileges for all accounts.

  6. Audit Log Management: Collecting, alerting on, reviewing, and retaining audit logs to aid in detecting and recovering from attacks.

  7. Data Protection: Identifying, classifying, and securely handling data throughout its lifecycle.

  8. Data Recovery: Establishing practices to restore assets to a trusted state after an incident.

  9. Incident Response Management: Establishing a program to prepare for, detect, and respond to security incidents.

  10. Email and Web Browser Protections: Enhancing protections against threats originating from email and web browsing.

  11. Continuous Vulnerability Management: Regularly assessing and remediating vulnerabilities on all assets.

  12. Malware Defence: Preventing the installation and execution of malicious code on enterprise assets.

  13. Network Infrastructure Management: Securely managing network devices to prevent exploitation.

  14. Network Monitoring and Defence: Maintaining comprehensive network monitoring to defend against threats.

  15. Application Software Security: Managing the security of software throughout its lifecycle.

  16. Penetration Testing: Testing the effectiveness of security controls by simulating attacker actions.

  17. Security Awareness and Skills Training: Implementing a program to educate the workforce on security best practices.

  18. Service Provider Management: Evaluating service providers to ensure they adequately protect sensitive data and critical platforms.

docs.title: Three implementation Groups
docs.text:
The CIS Controls are structured into three Implementation Groups (IGs 1-3) to accommodate organizations of different sizes and with different resources.

• IG1 (Basic Cyber Hygiene): This group consists of 56 Safeguards and represents the minimum standard of information security for all enterprises. It focuses on essential practices to defend against the most common attacks.

• IG2: Building upon IG1, this group adds 74 Safeguards, addressing a wider range of threats and vulnerabilities and suitable for organizations with moderate complexity.

• IG3: This group encompasses all 153 Safeguards, offering comprehensive protection against advanced threats and designed for larger organizations with significant resources and expertise.

docs.title: COBIT (Control Objectives for Information and related Technologies)
docs.text:
COBIT, developed by ISACA, is an IT governance and management framework that aligns IT processes with business goals, optimizes resource use, and provides metrics for performance and risk management. COBIT 2019 organizes its governance system into five domains, each containing processes that represent key activities for managing and governing enterprise IT. These domains are split between Governance Objectives and Management Objectives.

Five COBIT Domains and Their Process Groups

Domain Type Purpose EDM (Evaluate, Direct and Monitor) Governance Ensures stakeholder needs are evaluated, direction is set, and performance is monitored. APO (Align, Plan and Organize) Management Covers strategy, governance, and planning of IT. BAI (Build, Acquire and Implement) Management Focuses on implementation and integration of IT solutions. DSS (Deliver, Service and Support) Management Manages operational delivery of IT services. MEA (Monitor, Evaluate and Assess) Management Evaluates performance, compliance, and internal controls.

docs.title: Governance Domain
docs.text:
EDM – Evaluate, Direct and Monitor

Purpose: Provide board-level oversight to ensure IT delivers value, optimizes risk, and uses resources responsibly. Focuses on strategic oversight and decision-making.

Expand for the table Process Purpose Statement EDM01 Ensure Governance Framework Setting and Maintenance EDM02 Ensure Benefits Delivery EDM03 Ensure Risk Optimization EDM04 Ensure Resource Optimization EDM05 Ensure Stakeholder Engagement

Each EDM process includes:

• Purpose Statement: Why the process exists.

• Process Practices: Key activities to perform. e.g., define governance principles, monitor performance.

• Inputs/Outputs: Artifacts consumed and produced. E.g. governance policies, performance reports.

• Goals & Metrics: stakeholder satisfaction, risk posture.

• Governance Components: organizational structures, principles, policies.

docs.title: Management Domains
docs.text:
1.APO – Align, Plan and Organize

Purpose: Translate enterprise strategy and risk appetite into a coherent IT management framework and roadmap. Strategic planning, risk management, and resource alignment.

Expand for the table Process Purpose Statement APO01 Manage the IT Management Framework APO02 Manage Strategy APO03 Manage Enterprise Architecture APO04 Manage Innovation APO05 Manage Portfolio APO06 Manage Budget and Costs APO07 Manage Human Resources APO08 Manage Relationships APO09 Manage Service Agreements APO10 Manage Suppliers APO11 Manage Quality APO12 Manage Risk APO13 Manage Security

2.BAI – Build, Acquire and Implement

Purpose: Deliver new and changed IT solutions into operation securely and efficiently. Development, acquisition, and deployment of IT solutions.

Expand for the table Process Purpose Statement BAI01 Manage Programs and Projects BAI02 Manage Requirements Definition BAI03 Manage Solutions Identification and Build BAI04 Manage Availability and Capacity BAI05 Manage Organizational Change Enablement BAI06 Manage Changes BAI07 Manage Change Acceptance and Transitioning BAI08 Manage Knowledge BAI09 Manage Assets BAI10 Manage Configuration

3.DSS – Deliver, Service and Support

Purpose: Operate and support IT services securely, meeting agreed levels and responding to incidents. Operational delivery and support of IT services.

Expand for the table Process Purpose Statement DSS01 Manage Operations DSS02 Manage Service Requests and Incidents DSS03 Manage Problems DSS04 Manage Continuity DSS05 Manage Security Services DSS06 Manage Business Process Controls

4.MEA – Monitor, Evaluate and Assess Purpose: Provide assurance through monitoring performance, conformance, and compliance. Performance monitoring, compliance, and internal control.

Expand for the table Process Purpose Statement MEA01 Monitor, Evaluate and Assess Performance and Conformance MEA02 Monitor, Evaluate and Assess the System of Internal Control MEA03 Monitor, Evaluate and Assess Compliance with External Requirements

Governance Components in COBIT

Each process is supported by seven governance components:

  1. Processes

  2. Organizational Structures

  3. Information

  4. Culture, Ethics and Behavior

  5. People, Skills and Competencies

  6. Services, Infrastructure and Applications

  7. Policies and Procedures

These components ensure that each process is actionable, measurable, and aligned with enterprise goals. Goals and Metrics. COBIT uses performance management based on CMMI-like maturity levels - from Level 0 (Incomplete) to Level 5 (Optimizing).

docs.title: COSO Framework (Internal Control – Integrated Framework)
docs.text:
• Developed by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO). It was first introduced in 1992 and updated in 2013.

  • Provides a broad, principles-based framework for designing, implementing, and evaluating internal controls.

  • Built around 5 components (Control Environment, Risk Assessment, Control Activities, Information & Communication, Monitoring) and 17 principles.

Widely used for financial reporting, compliance, and enterprise risk management (e.g., SOX compliance).

docs.title: Relationship between COSO Framework and Common Criteria
1. The five Core Components of COSO
docs.text:
• Control Environment – Ethical tone, governance, and accountability culture.

  • Control Activities – Policies and procedures to mitigate risks.

  • Risk Assessment – Identifying and analysing risks to objectives.

  • Information & Communication – Sharing relevant, timely information internally and externally.

  • Monitoring Activities – Ongoing evaluation of control effectiveness.

docs.title: 2. Common Criteria (SOC 2 – Trust Services Criteria)
docs.text:
• Defined by the AICPA for System and Organization Controls (SOC 2) reporting.

  • Focuses on security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy.

  • The Common Criteria are the baseline requirements that apply across all Trust Services Categories (TSC) and then and then each category (Security, Confidentiality, Processing Integrity, Availability & Privacy) has additional criteria layered on top.

  • They are more specific to IT systems, service organizations, and SaaS providers.

docs.title: 3. How They Connect
docs.text:
• The AICPA Trust Services Criteria (Common Criteria) are explicitly aligned with COSO.

  • COSO provides the foundational internal control principles, while the Common Criteria adapt those principles to IT and service organization contexts.

  • For example:

    • COSO Principle: Control Environment → Common Criteria: Commitment to integrity, ethical values, and competence.

    • COSO Principle: Risk Assessment → Common Criteria: Identifying and assessing risks to system objectives.

docs.title: Mandatory: Common Criteria (CC) for TSC
docs.text:
CC1: Control Environment: Defines the organization's ethical values, integrity, and commitment to oversight.

CC2: Communication and Information: Addresses how organization communicate policies, procedures, and responsibilities to staff and external parties.

CC3: Risk Assessment: Covers how organization identifies and analyzes risks to its objectives.

CC4: Monitoring Activities: Ensures org has procedures to track and evaluate the effectiveness of controls over time.

CC5: Control Activities: Refers to the specific controls and technologies you implement to mitigate risks.

CC6: Logical and Physical Access Controls: Governs how your organization restricts logical (e.g., user credentials) and physical (e.g., server rooms) access to its systems and assets.

CC7: System Operations: Focuses on detecting and responding to system issues, including incident management and vulnerability monitoring.

CC8: Change Management: Covers the authorization, testing, and implementation of system changes.

CC9: Risk Mitigation: Deals with mitigating risks arising from business partners, vendors, and internal changes.

docs.title: CC1: Control Environment
docs.text:
Focus: Governance, ethics, accountability, competence.

Sub-classifications include:

CC1.1 – Commitment to integrity and ethical values

CC1.2 – Board independence and oversight

CC1.3 – Establishes structure, authority, and responsibility

CC1.4 – Commitment to competence

CC1.5 – Accountability for internal control responsibilities

docs.title: CC2: Communication & Information
docs.text:
Focus: Internal and external communication of policies and responsibilities.

Sub-classifications include:

CC2.1 – Uses relevant, quality information

CC2.2 – Communicates internally

CC2.3 – Communicates externally

docs.title: CC3: Risk Assessment
docs.text:
Focus: Identifying and analyzing risks, including fraud and change.

Sub-classifications include:

CC3.1 – Specifies suitable objectives

CC3.2 – Identifies and analyzes risks

CC3.3 – Assesses fraud risk

CC3.4 – Identifies and analyzes significant change

docs.title: CC4: Monitoring of Controls
docs.text:
Focus: Ongoing and separate evaluations of control effectiveness.

Sub-classifications include:

CC4.1 – Conducts ongoing and/or separate evaluations

CC4.2 – Evaluates and communicates deficiencies

docs.title: CC5: Control Activities
docs.text:
Focus: Policies, procedures, and IT general controls.

Sub-classifications include:

CC5.1 – Selects and develops control activities

CC5.2 – Selects and develops general controls over technology

CC5.3 – Deploys control activities through policies and procedures

docs.title: CC6: Logical & Physical Access Controls
docs.text:
Focus: Restricting access to systems, data, and facilities.

Sub-classifications include:

CC6.1 – Logical access security software, infrastructure, and architectures

CC6.2 – Registration and authorization of new/internal users

CC6.3 – Removal of access when no longer authorized

CC6.4 – Authentication mechanisms (e.g., MFA)

CC6.5 – Restricting physical access to facilities

CC6.6 – Securing workstations, laptops, and mobile devices

CC6.7 – Encryption and protection of data in transit and at rest

docs.title: CC7: System Operations
docs.text:
Focus: Managing operations, detecting anomalies, incident response.

Sub-classifications include:

CC7.1 – Detects and monitors system components

CC7.2 – Identifies and logs anomalies

CC7.3 – Assesses security events and incidents

CC7.4 – Responds to and mitigates incidents

CC7.5 – Recovers from incidents and resumes operations

docs.title: CC8: Change Management
docs.text:
Focus: Controlling changes to infrastructure, applications, and data.

Sub-classifications include:

CC8.1 – Authorizes and documents changes

CC8.2 – Tests, approves, and implements changes

CC8.3 – Restricts emergency changes and documents them

CC8.4 – Maintains version control and rollback procedures

docs.title: CC9: Risk Mitigation
docs.text:
Focus: Managing risks from vendors, partners, and external parties.

Sub-classifications include:

CC9.1 – Identifies and assesses risks from business partners and vendors

CC9.2 – Implements risk mitigation strategies (e.g., contracts, monitoring)

CC9.3 – Reviews and updates risk mitigation activities periodically

Key Takeaway

  • CC1–CC5 = Broad governance and internal control principles (aligned with COSO).

  • CC6–CC9 = IT and operational safeguards (access, operations, change, vendor risk).

docs.title: AICPA Trust Services Criteria
docs.text: Additional criteria layered on top of each TSC (Availability, Confidentiality, Processing Integrity, Privacy), also referred as the AICPA Trust Services Criteria .

docs.title: Availability
docs.text:
• Objective: Systems are available for operation and use as committed.
  • Criteria:
    • Common Criteria (CC1–CC9)
    • Additional Availability Criteria (A-Series):
      • A1.1: Availability commitments (e.g., uptime, SLAs)
      • A1.2: Backup and disaster recovery procedures
      • A1.3: Business continuity planning

docs.title: Confidentiality
docs.text:
• Objective: Information designated as confidential is protected.
  • Criteria:
    • Common Criteria (CC1–CC9)
    • Additional Confidentiality Criteria (C-Series):
      • C1.1: Identification and classification of confidential information
      • C1.2: Protection of confidential information during storage, transmission, and disposal.

docs.title: Processing Integrity
docs.text:
• Objective: System processing is complete, valid, accurate, timely, and authorized.
  • Criteria:
    • Common Criteria (CC1–CC9)
    • Additional Processing Integrity Criteria (PI-Series):
      • PI1.1: Input data validation
      • PI1.2: Processing accuracy and completeness
      • PI1.3: Output accuracy and completeness
      • PI1.4: Timeliness of processing
      • PI1.5: Authorization of processing activities

docs.title: Privacy
docs.text:
• Objective: Personal information is collected, used, retained, disclosed, and disposed of in line with commitments and privacy principles (adapted from GAPP).
  • Note: Useful when Service Organization is a data controller.
  • Criteria:
    • Common Criteria (CC1–CC9)
    • Additional Privacy Criteria (P-Series):
      • P1.1: Notice and communication of privacy practices
      • P1.2: Choice and consent
      • P1.3: Collection of personal information
      • P1.4: Use, retention, and disposal
      • P1.5: Access to personal information
      • P1.6: Disclosure to third parties
      • P1.7: Security for privacy (overlaps with CC6)
      • P1.8: Quality and monitoring of personal information

docs.title: Generally Accepted Privacy Principles (GAPP)
docs.text:
Generally Accepted Privacy Principles (GAPP) is a comprehensive privacy framework developed jointly by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants (AICPA) and the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants (CICA).

It’s 10 principles guides organizations—especially accounting firms and service providers—in designing, implementing, and maintaining effective privacy programs that manage personal information ethically and in line with legal requirements. Mandatory for publicly traded U.S. companies.

Framework Structure - GAPP is built on a single overarching privacy objective. Personal information must be collected, used, retained, and disclosed in accordance with the commitments in the organization’s privacy notice and with criteria defined in the GAPP framework.

This objective is supported by 10 Privacy Principles:

  1. Management: Defining and assigning accountability for privacy policies.

  2. Notice & Communication: Informing individuals about privacy policies and the purposes of data collection.

  3. Choice and consent: Providing individuals with options regarding the collection, use, and disclosure of their data.

  4. Collection: Limiting data collection to only what is necessary.

  5. Use, retention and disposal: Limiting the use of data to the stated purposes, retaining it only as long as necessary, and then disposing of it securely.

  6. Access: Giving individuals access to their personal information for review and updates.

  7. Disclosure to third parties: Limiting disclosure to third parties and requiring individual consent.

  8. Security for privacy: Protecting personal information with appropriate security measures.

  9. Quality: Maintaining accurate, complete, and relevant personal information.

  10. Monitoring and enforcement: Monitoring compliance and having procedures to address complaints.

Implementation and Benefits

  • Privacy Program Design: Use GAPP’s objectives and criteria to build policies, procedures, and controls.

  • SOC 2 Integration: GAPP aligns directly with SOC 2’s Privacy Trust Services Criteria, enabling streamlined audits.

  • Global Compliance: Provides a solid foundation for meeting regulations like GDPR and CCPA.

  • Accountability & Transparency: Embeds roles and responsibilities, risk assessments, and ongoing monitoring into the privacy program.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The NIST CSF 2.0 is a voluntary, risk-based framework designed by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology to help organizations of any size manage and reduce cybersecurity risk.

Core to CSF 2.0 are six functions that form a continuous improvement lifecycle:

  • Govern: Establish governance policies, roles, and oversight (new in 2.0).

  • Identify: Inventory assets, understand business context, and assess risk.

  • Protect: Implement safeguards such as access control, training, and data security.

  • Detect: Continuously monitor for anomalies and cybersecurity events.

  • Respond: Plan and execute actions to contain and mitigate incidents.

  • Recover: Restore systems and services while incorporating lessons learned.

Implementation Tiers: These describe the maturity of an organization's cybersecurity risk management, ranging from Partial (Tier 1) to Adaptive (Tier 4), indicating a progression from less formal to more proactive approaches.

docs.title: NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5.1.1 controls
docs.text:
The most comprehensive and standardized catalog of security and privacy controls (it defines controls – not just policies) used across U.S. federal agencies, critical infrastructure, and increasingly by private enterprises for robust cybersecurity governance.

Full name: Security and Privacy Controls for Information Systems and Organizations

What Are NIST SP 800-53 Controls?

  • Developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).

  • Provides a catalog of 400+ controls for securing information systems and protecting privacy.

  • Used to implement FISMA, FedRAMP, and align with NIST CSF, ISO 27001, and other frameworks.

  • Controls are grouped into 20 families, each addressing a specific security domain.

docs.title: NIST 20 Control Families
docs.text:
Expand for the table Family Group Family Code Control Family Purpose Access & Identity AC Access Control Manage who can access systems and data (e.g., AC-01: Access Control Policy, AC-02: Account Management) Access & Identity IA Identification and Authentication Verify user identities (e.g., IA-02: User Identification and Authentication) Assessment & Accountability CA Security Assessment and Authorization Assess and authorize systems (e.g., CA-07: Continuous Monitoring) Assessment & Accountability AU Audit and Accountability Log and monitor system activity (e.g., AU-06: Audit Review, AU-12: Audit Generation) Protection & Integrity SC System and Communications Protection Secure data in transit and at rest (e.g., SC-12: Cryptographic Key Establishment) Protection & Integrity SI System and Information Integrity Detect and correct flaws (e.g., SI-04: Information System Monitoring) Protection & Integrity PT Privacy Protect personally identifiable information (e.g., PT-01: Privacy Program Governance) Protection & Integrity MP Media Protection Protect physical and digital media (e.g., MP-05: Media Transport Protection) Protection & Integrity PE Physical and Environmental Protection Secure physical access and environmental controls (e.g., PE-03: Emergency Shutoff) Governance & Planning PL Planning Define security plans and strategies (e.g., PL-02: System Security Plan) Governance & Planning PM Program Management Overarching governance and privacy controls (e.g., PM-21: Privacy Risk Assessment) Governance & Planning SA System and Services Acquisition Ensure secure procurement and development (e.g., SA-11: Developer Security Testing) Governance & Planning SR Supply Chain Risk Management Manage third-party and vendor risks (e.g., SR-06: Supplier Assessments) Risk & Response RA Risk Assessment Identify and evaluate risks (e.g., RA-05: Vulnerability Monitoring) Risk & Response IR Incident Response Detect and respond to security incidents (e.g., IR-04: Incident Handling) Risk & Response CP Contingency Planning Ensure recovery from disruptions (e.g., CP-09: System Backup) Operations & Personnel MA Maintenance Secure system maintenance procedures (e.g., MA-05: Maintenance Personnel) Operations & Personnel PS Personnel Security Screen and manage personnel (e.g., PS-03: Personnel Termination) Operations & Personnel AT Awareness and Training Educate users and staff on security practices (e.g., AT-02: Security Awareness Training) Operations & Personnel CM Configuration Management Maintain secure system configurations (e.g., CM-02: Baseline Configuration)

Control Baselines - NIST defines three impact levels:

  • Low: ~149 controls

  • Moderate: ~287 controls

  • High: ~370 controls

These baselines help tailor control selection based on system sensitivity and risk exposure.

Control Structure - Each control includes:

  • Control statement: What must be done (e.g., “The organization must manage user accounts.”).

  • Control enhancements: Optional add-ons for higher assurance.

  • Discussion: Rationale and examples.

  • Implementation guidance: How to apply it in real-world systems.

What’s New in Rev. 5.1.1 (2023–2025)

  • Rev. 5 (latest version) integrates privacy controls alongside security — making it suitable for GDPR, HIPAA, and other privacy regimes.

  • New controls for identity providers, cryptographic key protection, and token management.

  • Enhanced mappings to NIST CSF 2.0, ISO/IEC 27001:2022, and the NIST Privacy Framework.

  • Leading zeros added to control IDs (e.g., AC-01 instead of AC-1) for consistency.

Primary Reference: NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5.1.1

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The report is created and validated by third-party auditors, which is built to provide independent assurance and verify that an organization is following specific best practices for business functions outsourced.

SOC 2 reporting is based on SSAE 18 attestation standard which is a general framework for CPAs (Certified Public Accountants) to perform attestation engagements — where an independent auditor examines and reports on subject matter other than traditional financial statements.

SSAE 18 (in 2017) which has superseded the AT 101 (previous standard), but the concepts from AT 101 still underpin SOC 2 reporting. AT 101 was not industry-specific framework (financial & non-financial) but it could be used for security, privacy, compliance, or other assurance topics.

The SOC 2 controls are not fixed checklist because the framework is principles-based (COSO) rather than prescriptive. Controls are derived from the five Trust Services Criteria (TSC), which are defined by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants (AICPA).

The 5 Trust Services criterias

Security, Availability, Processing integrity, Confidentiality, Privacy. Security controls testing is mandatory, while the rest (availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy) are optional.

Report Type

  • Type I: Design of controls at a specific point in time.

  • Type II: Design and operating effectiveness of controls over a period (typically 6–12 months).

docs.title: Service Auditor
docs.text:
• An independent CPA firm or audit professional who performs the SOC 2 examination.

  • They assess whether the service organization’s controls meet the Trust Services Criteria. They issue the final SOC 2 report, which includes their opinion on the design and/or operating effectiveness of control.

docs.title: Service Organization
docs.text:
• This is the company being audited in a SOC 2 report.

  • It provides services to other businesses (user entities), often involving data processing, cloud hosting, SaaS platforms, or IT infrastructure.

docs.title: Sub-Service Organization
docs.text:
• A third-party vendor that the service organization relies on to deliver part of its service.

  • Example: A SaaS company using AWS for cloud hosting — AWS is the sub-service organization.

There are two ways sub-service organization are handled in SOC 2:

  • Inclusive Method: Their controls are included and tested in the SOC 2 report.

  • Carve-Out Method: Their controls are excluded, but the service organization must describe what’s outsourced and what risks are involved.

docs.title: User Entity
docs.text:
• A client or customer of the service organization.

  • They rely on the service organization’s systems and controls to protect their data and operations.

  • Example: A bank using a third-party document management system.

docs.title: CUECs (Complementary User Entity Controls)
docs.text:
• These are controls that the user entity is responsible for.

  • The service organization assumes these controls are in place at the user entity to ensure the overall system works securely.

  • Example: If a service organization provides secure file sharing, the user entity must revoke access for terminated employees — the service organization on its own.

SOC 2 reports list CUECs so user entities know what they must do to uphold the shared security model.

docs.title: Report Components
docs.text: A SOC 2 report has five main parts, focusing on an organization's security controls related to one or more of the AICPA's Trust Services Criteria. The sections provide details on the management's view of the audit, the auditor's official opinion, a description of the system under review, the testing results, and other information.

docs.title: Section I: Management's assertion
docs.text:
This section is drafted by the audited organization's management and outlines:

  • A summary of the services and systems covered by the audit.

  • A formal statement that the system description is presented fairly and that the controls were suitably designed.

  • A declaration of the service commitments and requirements addressed in the report.

  • Confirmation that management provided all relevant information to the auditor.

docs.title: Section II: Independent Service Auditor's report
docs.text:
This is the auditor's summary and opinion on the audit and is often the most important section for users of the report. It includes:

  • The scope and timeframe of the audit.

  • A description of the responsibilities of both management and the auditor.

  • The auditor's opinion: The final grade on the audit. Opinions can be:

    • Unqualified: The highest assurance, meaning controls are designed and operating effectively.

    • Qualified: Indicates that the controls have some deficiencies but are generally effective.

    • Adverse: A failure of the audit, indicating that controls are not effective and the system is unreliable.

    • Disclaimer of Opinion: The auditor was unable to form an opinion due to a lack of evidence.

docs.title: Section III: System description
docs.text:
This part, written by the service organization, provides a detailed overview of the system being audited. It is often the longest section and typically includes:

  • System components: The infrastructure, software, procedures, people, and data that are part of the system.

  • System boundaries: What is and is not included in the audit's scope.

  • Incidents and changes: Any system incidents or significant changes that occurred during the audit period.

  • Controls and processes: An explanation of the relevant security policies, risk management, and procedures.

docs.title: Section IV: Applicable Trust Services Criteria and test results
docs.text:
This section details how the organization addresses each of the applicable Trust Services Criteria (TSC).

  • Trust Services Criteria: All SOC 2 audits must cover the Security criterion, with other TSCs like Availability, Confidentiality, Processing Integrity, and Privacy being optional.

  • Controls and tests: It lists the controls put in place by the organization for each criterion, the test procedures the auditor performed, and the results of that testing. For a Type 2 report, this section also shows whether the controls operated effectively over time and notes any exceptions.

docs.title: Section V: Other information (optional)
docs.text:
In this final, non-audited section, management can provide additional context. It may be used to:

  • Explain the company's response to any exceptions or issues found by the auditor.

  • Detail future plans for system improvements.

  • Offer additional details about the company's control environment.

docs.title: SOC 3:
docs.text:
• A public-facing version of a SOC 2 Type II that does not include confidential information.

  • Provides a high-level summary for general customers without compromising or revealing details on the internal controls.

  • Usually only utilized by organizations that have conducted many SOC reports in the past and have a robust and mature control environment.
